results.title: Sunny and the dark horse
results.creator_credit: David MacDougall, Judith MacDougall and AIAS Film Unit
results.brief_description: This is a companion to the documentaries ‘Stockman’s Strategy’ and ‘Collum Calling Canberra’. Sunny Bancroft, the Aboriginal manager of a co-operative cattle station in northern New South Wales is the central ‘character’ in what is the most narratively-oriented of the trilogy. We follow Sunny as he indulges his passion for horses by acquiring and training a galloper for the picnic races.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David MacDougall, Judith MacDougall and AIAS Film Unit

results.title: The Spag [released version]
results.brief_description: Director Giorgio Mangiamele produced the first examples of multicultural cinema in this country. ‘The Spag’ was shot in the streets of Carlton and tells the story of a newspaper boy working to support his widowed mother; along the way his life is fraught with racism. The film is Neo-Realist in style and makes interesting use of incidental music and post-sync dubbed dialogue track; a dog’s bark is even mimicked by an actor’s voice. Stars the young Terry Donovan.

results.title: The Gallery
results.creator_credit: Phillip Mark-Law, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: This film about the National Gallery of Victoria is beautifully conceived and deserves its many film festival awards. Kerry Brown (editor) and Graham Chase (cinematographer) provide stunning contrasts, dissolves and cut images of the architectural design and art holdings. The Great Hall with its lead light ceiling and water window is also featured. These images are complimented by Leslie Dempsey’s impressive electronic score. This film is carefully composed without voice-over narration. Winner of top awards at film festivals in Cork, Brussels, San Francisco, Melbourne and Chicago. Edited by Graham Chase. No spoken commentary.

results.title: Way to a New World
results.creator_credit: Richard Mason, Maslyn Williams, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The old and the new in Papua New Guinea. The traditional way of life in the villages; trade with other villages, the belief in magic, raising garden crops, management of village affairs by the old men in secret, feasts and sing-sings, the initiation of the young men. The new ways; opportunities for education, improved health and child welfare, the introduction of cash crops and native cooperation associations, the formation of elected Local Government Councils.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Mason, Maslyn Williams, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Native Earth
results.creator_credit: John Heyer and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A study of Australia’s responsibilities and administration issues in Papua New Guinea immediately after World War 2, with particular emphasis on the life and the needs of Papuans. Commentary by Peter Finch, researched by Catherine Duncan, script by Catherine Duncan, photography by Frank Bagnall, music by John Kay.

results.title: Namatjira the painter. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes, Ralph Foster and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The story of Albert Namatjira, who once worked as a cook and camel-boy for the landscape painter Rex Batterbee. Namatjira became interested in painting and under Batterbee’s tuition, began to use watercolours to reproduce on canvas the Central Australian landscape. This vintage film, made at the height of Namatjira’s popularity shows the painter at work and discusses the influence of the environment on his beautiful original landscapes. Rich with illustrations of his work, this film is a tribute to the painter. Original ed. [307974].
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stanley Hawes, Ralph Foster and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Mexico 75: no place else in the world to be
results.creator_credit: Patricia Edgar and Centre for the Study of Educational Communication and Media, LaTrobe University
results.brief_description: A record of the International Women’s Conference in Mexico City in 1975. The film sets the Conference in the context of an underdeveloped country and discusses the relevance of the women’s movement to third world countries. There is special emphasis on the contribution of the Australian delegation.

results.title: Jafar's blue tiles (Iran)
results.creator_credit: Paul Saltzman, Deepa Mehta and Sunrise Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World cultures and youth”.
The restoration of a 600-year-old brick dome in his village is the focal point of fourteen-year-old Jafar’s interests and activities as he is seen making and installing twelve richly colored tiles that adorn the dome. Told from Jafar’s point of view, explains the significance of the project and the brickmaking process in the culture and customs of his country and captures vistas of the Iranian landscape.

results.title: Space flight
results.brief_description: Made by a special “Plasti-Cine” technique, in this film the hero, Dan, passes an amusing set of tests for health fitness, then flies a space rocket to the planet Venus. After battling the demon Nicotine, Dan persuades the Venusians to destroy the groves of cigarette trees to abolish smoking.

After battling the demon Nicotine, Dan persuades the Venusians to destroy the groves of cigarette trees to abolish smoking.

results.title: Kurtis: Hollywood stuntboy
results.creator_credit: Paul Quigley, Peter Rowe and Sunrise Films Ltd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World cultures and youth”.
Kurtis Sanders is a 12 year old stuntman. The film shows stunts Kurtis and his family perform for a television special illustrating stuntwork. It also shows original footage of old westerns in which Kurtis’s grandfather was a stuntman.
